I am assuming that Russia will be fully engaged in Syria for the next 4 months. There could be a possibility that an incident connected to this conflict could prompt Turkey to invoke Article 4 (again). I am not sure if a clash between Russia and NATO countries forces in Syria would meet the criteria for Article 4 as it would presumably not threaten the Territorial Integrity, Political Independence or Security of any NATO country. 
Its possible that Russia could provoke an incident somewhere else, possibly in the period after US elections and the new US President taking office, if it thought that the US might be slow to react, with the aim to have occupied some territory before NATO reacted. It is possible that Russia might provoke an incident in order to get a reaction from the US that might affect the US elections. (e.g. create an incident in Transnistria that threatened Moldova and Romania, Romania being in NATO, hoping to stir up rhetoric that would improve Trump's chances of getting elected, which Putin sees as being to his advantage. 
But none of these possibilities seems very likely.

Sitrep Stratfor Inc (c 2016)
September 22, 2016 | 12:53 GMT
A Turkish presidential spokesman reiterated on Sept. 22 that Turkish forces would not participate in a coalition offensive to retake the Islamic State's de facto capital of Raqqa if Kurdish fighters are involved, Reuters reported. Turkey considers U.S.-backed People's Protection Units (YPG) to be terrorists connected to Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) insurgents who operate inside Turkey. The spokesman's statement comes the day after news broke that the White House is considering directly arming YPG fighters for the first time, as reported by the New York Times. The move is representative of the tightrope the United States has to walk in Syria: The YPG has been one of the most effective forces fighting against the Islamic State, but sending weapons to Kurdish fighters would surely aggravate Turkey.

Comment:  For domestic purposes in the run up to Russian elections within two weeks on 18/9/16, Mr. Putin is active on the global stage looking to be very Presidential for those few Russians that... eventually decide... to go to the polls (Footnote 3). In point of substantive fact, the Russian voter has virtually NO option  as Putin is his own next viable candidate. (4)  Nonetheless, on the one hand, if not making waves at the G20 Summit at HANGZHOU, China calling US & Russian relations "frozen" on various Syrian issues (1), then Mr.
Putin is making a clear effort at improving relations with Japan PM Abe (2). He is making every effort to remain in the global/geopolitical eye.  On the other hand, in the Middle East, as Putin continues to face of VARIOUS & SUNDRY UN EMBARGO initiatives, he nonetheless makes a serious effort to craft a complex tripartite relationship between Iran, Turkey & Russia on the issue of extending Assad's continued existence as leader of Syria (5). Questionable, but to date effective,  for both Putin & Assad. NB: IRAN remains also extremely supportive of Assad as well. (5a) All backward looking analysis.  Forward looking probability variations include the fact that Putin is still Putin. Probability calculation is therefore extremely low.  This said, is there not a is a risk of OVER estimating his impact?  (6) That is, in spite of their relatively underweighted geopolitical economic impact, the Russians continue to stir up an overweighted concern to many Eastern European Countries that view a Russian military build up on their respective borders as troublesome.(7) However, is such a move PRIMARILY for domestic consumption or, are there more nefarious motives? (7).  All extremely relevant questions to a NATO member Country invoking Article 4. Importantly, at least for Putin, the Germans continue to be a critical counter-weight to a NATO Article 4 push by any Eastern European Country. NB: Putinversteher (8)  Putin recognize, and takes geopolitical leverage / advantage, of this fact that Germans abhor & will do their upmost to avoid at all costs, saber rattling as their borders as they are at risk and, continue to exert significant influence on this issue.  Thus, a forward looking, hopefully  imaginative out of the box analysis, includes what probabilities the RARELY used NATO Article 4 provision can be used by " other NATO" members?(9)  In light of the above-mentioned fact that Eastern European Countries face a difficult counterweight in Germany to calling on NATO Article 4 provisions, proper analysis leaves historical considerations, including Turkey which does have a history of taking advantage of the NATO provision (9). CAVEAT: Here as well, Putin has made a progress with Erdogan on the issue of the recent unsuccessful military coup. Putin may have provided, through his security apparatus, notice to Erdogan that he must be careful. A warning. (10). Such a scenario leaves Erdogan & Putin, at least for the foreseeable future, in the same camp. Thus, Turkey would also be an unlikely candidate to invoke a NATO Article 4 call.  Conclusion: Slightly over, one hundred & twenty days (120) remain towards resolution of this GJ Q. Russian elections are purely procedural with no substantive change. Erdogan has taken over Turkey's military & economic apparatus. There is a certain "closer relationship" btw the two Countries.  The Germans continue to act as a counterweight to real Eastern European concerns on Russian borderline forays. The US elections are a further "wait and see" element for all Parties at stake on this NATO Article 4 Q.  Weighing the sum of all the above-mentioned geopolitical parts, there is marginal probability any NATO member will invoke Article 4 in response to actions taken by Russia b/f 1/1/17. Article 4 has been invoked 3 times in 2003, twice in 2012, once in 2013, and was discussed in 2014 by Turkey. Given the increased frequency of encounters between Russia and NATO members in recent past, it definitely increases the odds. Given that 2/3 of 2016 being over and a rate of one invocation per year, I'm starting with a 33% approximation. But given the desire of NATO members to avoid conflict (even non-armed conflict), I'm lowering this to 25%.

Since 2012 Article 4 has been invoked 4 times, before that only once, twice in 2012 by Turkey over the Syrian Civil War, after the downing of an unarmed Turkish F-4 reconnaissance jet, and after a mortar was fired at Turkey from Syria; in 2014 by Poland, following the Russian intervention in Crimea; and again by Turkey in 2015 after threats by the Islamic State to its territorial integrity. This means the run rate is about 1 a year recently but hardly ever before. With only a half year to go I calibrate the chance between the recent and the historical run rate

Up from 5 to 10%. COMMENT:
Hypothesis: 
Are we witness to an increasing probability of a partial breakdown of globalization ? Over the past six months, there have been a number of events that - standing alone - do not provide sufficient justification for a NATO member to invoke Article 4. However, when one combines the totality of near encroachments, border line issues &, generally pervasive attitude of distrust on both sides, a clear trend is taking place.  Attached self explanatory. 13/7/16 NATO - Russia Council ( NRC) meeting will also have "permanent representatives" in attendance. Whether the meeting goes beyond, the parameters set out ( close call encounters b/w Russian & Western aircraft over the Baltic) is open to speculation.  This mornings news follows, interesting developments recently. The NATO maneuvers in Poland. The German more conciliatory message to avoid saber-rattling discussion.  This past week, Turkey & Russia attempting to re-establish relations w/ Turkish apologies for aircraft shooting incident on the one hand  & lifting Russian travel bans to Turkey on the other hand.  Lots of recent CROSS CURRENTS.  A thankful move, at least,  for Russians who enjoy Belek vacations &, Turkish tourism in desperate need of tourism post the recent terrorism in Turkey.  It's impossible to get inside Putin's head reference his  actions that led to sanctions in the Ukraine & Crimea in the first instance. Syria is exemplary of how he can maneuver nonetheless on the geopolitical stage. Successfully for his particular Interests.  Staying in power is certainly a Putin major objective. That said, there  still a deep distrust that works both ways - NATO & Russia.  I had to nudge - myself -  to recall that Russia was in the 1990s, a truly tortuous land. A dark period. Being Russian, & recalling this close to depression & lawless period, one has a very real bias for more control. Strength of the state vs weakness & lawlessness.  That said, Russians have also not been "informed" of the expansion of member states to the EU. Which obviously includes a NATO related expansion. Post BREXIT, & the ongoing misguided punditry discussion of EU breakup scenarios, such discussion simply adds momentum to Putins underling thesis that " THE EU has been a bankrolled" process for some nations & "a bankrupt" process for other Member states. FURTHER, EU instability can only play POSITIVELY towards Putins hand and, should not be under-estimated. One potential flashpoint may be the Republic of Moldova: large-scale pro-Russia protests have been unfolding in the capital, Chisinau, in the past week, with a tent city (echoes of past pro-Western protests in Kiev) being set up. There are obvious ways in which Russia can meddle via its proxies in Parliament (the Socialist Party - the largest parliamentary faction, but excluded from Government), the separatist territory of Gagauzia (in which an unofficial referendum last year overwhelmingly expressed support for joining Russia's Eurasian Economic Union), and via its troops and allies in the secessionist region of Transnistria. That the Government is weak, unstable, and the credibility of the state is severely exhausted by major acts of financial fraud and malpractice is also significant. A potential pro-Russian uprising or escalation in Moldova would certainly be a cause of great concern for Romania, which shares a great deal of heritage and culture with Moldova. It might be plausible for Romania to invoke Article 4 if it felt threatened by Russian acts in Moldova, akin to how Poland did so with regard to Russian acts in Ukraine  - specifically the annexation of Crimea - in 2014. That Romania's relationship with Moldova is closer than that of Poland to Ukraine, and the geographical context entirely different - Moldova is a small country - suggests that an act as strong as annexation might not be necessary to invoke such action on Romania's part.

Turkey might be considered the most probable NATO member to invoke Article 4, with specific regard to Russian actions in Syria. Turkey has invoked Article 4 more times than any other country (four times, three of them directly concerning the situation in Syria, in 2012, 2012 and 2015.  Turkey and Russia's position in Syria remain at odds with one another, and both countries are led by "strongmen" leaders. The other occasion on which Article 4 has been invoked in the past five years was by Poland, in response to Russia's annexation of Crimea from Ukraine. The coming to power of a more nationalistic, and frankly paranoid, and strongly anti-Russian, government in Poland is also worth noting: any actions taken by Russia, in non-NATO member states, that may be regarded as a potential threat to European/Western security, could reasonably expect some kind of response from the NATO states of Eastern and Central Europe, and perhaps Poland above all. (Provocations directly involving the Baltic States do not fall into this category: as they are all NATO members, Article 5 would be the appropriate response - with severe, military consequences.).   A stepping up of military basing in the Russian Baltic Exclave of Kaliningrad (something that has been "threatened" - and partly implemented - on numerous occasions) might fit the criteria that might result in Article 4 being invoked by the most strongly anti-Russian NATO states, Poland and Lithuania (both of which neighbour the territory).  Alternatively, an upsurge of violence in the Donbass - or the unfreezing of the conflict in Transnistria, or Russian subversion in Moldova proper (which cannot be ruled out: Russia has being building up its support, quite blatantly, in the Moldovan autonomous territory of Gagauzia in recent years - which almost unanimously approved a referendum in support of joining Russia's Eurasian Union, in preference to the European Union: while the Moldovan Government is weak, seemingly perpetually unstable (one former Prime Minister currently under arrest, one forced to resign - on the slightly spurious grounds that he had forged his high school graduation certificate, one recently removed from  office in a vote of no confidence ....), while a financial scandal (involving the theft of a substantial quantity of banking assets) has further weakened state credibility.  Large-scale anti-Government protests in Montenegro recently too, in response against that country's plans to join NATO in the near future. Russia may or may not have been directly involved in those, but at the moment (perhaps: on past form, just for the moment), the Russian state media is working overtime to portray the situation in Montenegro in the worst possible light - seemingly part of its policy (modified beyond its "near abroad"), seen in Armenia and Ukraine, to force countries to choose whether to align themselves with Russia or with the West (NATO and/or the EU). Renewed tensions within Georgia - more likely over South Ossetia than the rather more complex and multifaceted situation in Abkhazia - provide another potential trigger-point. And the North Pole/Arctic. Many possibilities. The prospect of a situation eventually occurring that might result in Article 4 being evoked in each one is relatively low (Syria by far seeming the most likely), but with active and unresolved conflicts, and a timespan of 14 months, such a series of events cannot be ruled out.

NATO member states that can invoke Article 4 with credibility, based upon geographical proximity to Ukraine, is limited to 4: Poland, Bulgaria, Romania and Turkey. Military personnel (active and reserve) in both Turkey (1m) and Poland (635k) is significant whilst that in Bulgaria (300k) and Romania (150k). The invocation of Article 4 would unlikely be motivated by a genuine military threat against any of these nations by Russia. Instead, it is more likely that Article 4, which triggers a gathering of all NATO member states, would be used to as an opportunity to re-affirm international opinion against Russia's actions in Ukraine and, in doing so, solidify support for the maintenance of the sanctions against Russia. A politically-inspired, rather than militarily motivated invocation, is therefore plausible. NATO website states: "In Article 4 of NATO’s founding treaty, members are encouraged to bring subjects to the table for discussion within the North Atlantic Council, the principal forum for political consultation." (source http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/topics_49187.htm). Though article 4 has only been invoked 5 times since the creation of NATO, it has been used twice recently by both Poland (in 2014 concerning Russia) and Turkey (in 2015 regarding Syria). As an outside bet, Ukraine itself could potentially become a NATO member (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Individual_Partnership_Action_Plan) and therefore invoke article 4 however the timetable for membership almost certainly extends beyond 1 Jan 2017. The recent visit to Kyiv by the NATO Secretary General, during which agreements were signed to formalise the NATO’s diplomatic representation in Ukraine, to support communications, and to strengthen technical cooperation on defence highlights the desire to bring Ukraine on board.
